title: [MA] New tests being misreported as total molecular + postive antibody
body:
Output from covid19-datafetch for Massachusetts yields this table (null columns removed for brevity):

STATE | FETCH_TIMESTAMP | POSITIVE | TOTAL | CURR_HOSP | HOSP | CURR_ICU | CURR_VENT | DEATH_PROBABLE | DEATH_CONFIRMED | PROBABLE | DATE | ANTIBODY_TOTAL | SPECIMENS
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
MA | 1594767517.597360 | 105986 | 972070 | 560 | 11625 | 93 | 37 | 215 | 8125 | 6144 | 7/14/2020 | 81525 | 1241465

And here's today's corresponding output:

date | state | positive | negative | pending | hospitalizedCurrently | hospitalizedCumulative | inIcuCurrently | inIcuCumulative | onVentilatorCurrently | onVentilatorCumulative | recovered | dataQualityGrade | lastUpdateEt | dateModified | checkTimeEt | death | hospitalized | dateChecked | totalTestsViral | positiveTestsViral | negativeTestsViral | positiveCasesViral | deathConfirmed | deathProbable | fips | positiveIncrease | negativeIncrease | total | totalTestResults | totalTestResultsIncrease | posNeg | deathIncrease | hospitalizedIncrease | hash | commercialScore | negativeRegularScore | negativeScore | positiveScore | score | grade
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
20200714 | MA | 112130 | 866084 |   | 560 | 11625 | 93 |   | 37 |   | 94347 | A+ | 7/14/2020 10:00 | 2020-07-14T10:00:00Z | 07/14 06:00 | 8340 | 11625 | 2020-07-14T10:00:00Z | 1241465 |   |   | 105986 | 8125 | 215 | 25 | 303 | 11768 | 978214 | 978214 | 12071 | 978214 | 10 | 14 | 223685fc192453cac71c42ba8e03d499630ee80e | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0


As far as I understand from reading over the code, the total test results in the output are calculated from `positive + negative + probable` from the datafetch input (where `negative = total - positive`, so `total + probable`). For reference, the value from the output table above is 978214.

This count leaves out negative antibody tests.  A correct count for `total` in the public api should be `positive + negative + antibody_total`, which would total 1053595 in the example.

title: [OH]Review historicals for mismatches with Ohio's page
body: From a Front ticket: "I am an avid COVID-19 tracker from Cincinnati. I refer to your Ohio page regularly to get testing data, and share that with my social network. But your recent chart showing zero cases on July 2nd a large spike in new cases on July 3rd caught my attention. This information is wrong. So, I double checked the rest of July and found every single date was wrongly reported. I did not check June's info. July 1 you reported 1,076 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 1,041 July 2 you reported 0 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 1,260 July 3 you reported 2,392 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 1,058. July 4 you reported 926 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 907 July 5 you reported 968 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 970 July 6 you reported 805 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 774 July 7 you reported 948 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 918 July 8 you reported 1,277 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 1,234 July 9 you reported 1,150 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 1,122 July 10 you reported 1,525 new cases; actual new Ohio cases were 1,494 Incidentally, the number of new cases on July 10th was our highest to date. And we have not had any date with zero cases reported since we started reporting on or about March 8th. I strongly encourage you to correct the Ohio errors, or take down the page." [Front conversations](https://app.frontapp.com/open/top_25y6p)

title: [PR] Historical Puerto Rico hospitalizations data
body:
**State or US**: Puerto Rico

**Describe the problem**

So, on Thursday (July 9) the number of COVID-19 hospitalizations in Puerto Rico climbed to 147, prompting a leading local paper to publish a story pointing out that, according to the data they had, this was a record high:

* ["Record patients: hospitalizations for COIVD-19 increase to 147"](https://www.elnuevodia.com/noticias/locales/notas/record-de-pacientes-las-hospitalizaciones-por-covid-19-aumentan-a-147/) *El Nuevo Día*, July 9, 2020.

This seemingly didn't sit well with the Secretary of Health, who responded by saying that his department's records refute this and that there were 201 hospitalizations on April 30:

* https://twitter.com/DeptSaludPR/status/1281261229403713537

And as part of this, he also shared a table of historical hospitalization data with some journalists. It goes from April 18 to July 9, and also breaks the totals down by region:

* https://twitter.com/angelicaserran0/status/1281256666881802241
* https://twitter.com/RobbyCortes/status/1281536898230558720

I have dutifully transcribed this data into a CSV, and used a spreadsheet to check that the regional totals add up to the listed totals:

* https://github.com/sacundim/covid-19-puerto-rico/blob/master/assets/data/PuertoRico-hospitalizations.csv

* https://twitter.com/angelicaserran0/status/1281694446233497602

title: [WV] PCL Cases Historical

labels.name: Backfill
labels.description: Backfill histoircal data from state provided sources

body:
**State or US**: West Virginia

**Describe the problem**
1. Historical "Positive Cases (PCR)" goes back until 4/29. There's a gap from 5/22 - 6/4 (https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/issues/issues/555) that we may be able to fill now.

2. States Daily antibody test values go back until 5/23, but our long formulas sheet dates back to 4/12. The WV website has hover-over line graphs that date back to 3/17 for cases and 3/11 for lab tests.

3. Under the "Positive Case Trends" tab, cumulative historical cases on the WV website combine probable and confirmed cases, but in the graph underneath, historical daily cases are separated by probable and confirmed cases. Since WV updates data multiple times every day and backfills their own data consistently, current CTP historical values for cases and testing do not match with the hover-over line graphs on the WV website. 

**Link to data source**
Dashboard: https://dhhr.wv.gov/COVID-19/Pages/default.aspx 
Daily Press Releases (at 10AM and 5PM): https://dhhr.wv.gov/News/2020/Pages/default.aspx

title: [Data Quality] Filling in complete timeseries for confirmed cases
body:
**Target Date**: 08/01

**Overview**: Fill in the timeseries for positiveCasesViral in the API (also known as “Positive Cases (PCR)” on Worksheet2) to enable calculating totals with confirmed+neg instead of pos+neg.
**Contribution to Milestone**: This measure will ensure our technique of calculating totals for each state by cases+negatives does not include probable cases in our total tested counts when we can prevent it.
**Other Benefits**: This milestone will also support changing our website graphs to graph just confirmed cases rather than confirmed+probable by drawing on the backfilled confirmed field.
**Potential Challenges**:
States may not all provide sources we can backfill from, and if they do the strategies of dating cases used in those historicals may not be by date reported and therefore may not match our time-series. We will need to decide what to do.
Backfilling confirmed cases will have cascading effects requiring updates to states where we were calculating negatives by totals - lumped cases. In these cases, negatives calculation will need to be updated to totals - confirmed cases.
Before states started separating out confirmed cases, there may be discontinuities in the timeseries (e.g. the totals number may suddenly appear to drop the day we switch from using a state’s lumped numbers to confirmed ones).
**Editorial**: None for this issue. We will release editorial along with #676 

- [x] Revamp the PCL Cases spreadsheet
- [x] Checks on PCL Cases
- [x] Double Checks on PCL Cases
- [ ] Submit outreach on states with unclear PCL Cases policies and modify labels according to answers
- [ ] DQ investigates “Positive Cases (PCR)” history by investigating States Daily for historicals filing GitHub issues for any states with incomplete historical time-series 
   _Note: we accidentally began this process without DCing our labels, so we are reviewing the issues we filed before DCs._
- [ ] DQ resolves the issues, calling in backfill team for help when they are especially thorny

title: [NY] Fill in some missing Current Hospitalizations & Current ICU from dash that were not supplied in emails
body:
Hello,

I build and update a coronavirus tracker for Crain's New York Business. The COVID Tracking Project is a great source for us, but I wanted to point out a few apparent errors I believe I've spotted in the New York data.

**Metric: Current Hospitalizations** 
In the hospitalizations data, the COVID Tracking Project is reporting some numbers that don't match up with the figures the state is publishing in its own dashboard. These could be typos or results of the state's revisions to hospitalization figures in the days that followed. Here are the updated numbers I'm using in my own tracker, which subtracts a day from the Tracking Project dates so it matches state sources:
Date,Revised hospitalizations
"2020-04-14",18335
"2020-04-16",17316
"2020-04-20",16135
"2020-04-27",12646
"2020-05-04",9600
"2020-05-22",4642

**Metric: Current ICU**
 I should also note that the [New York dashboard](https://forward.ny.gov/daily-hospitalization-summary-region) contains daily ICU numbers. Those could be used to fill in the gap in the COVID Tracking Project's ICU data (spanning from 4/27 through 5/6) and to update existing numbers. For instance, the current figures from the Tracking Project have 5,016 ICU admissions daily between 4/18 and 4/26, whereas the actual numbers reported by the state continuously decreased.

title: [PR] Official testing data for Puerto Rico
body:
**State or US**: Puerto Rico

**Describe the problem**

Since Puerto Rico's Department of Health doesn't publish tests data regularly, and when it does it doesn't do so in any manner or medium that's amenable to automatic capture, the testing data in the Project for Puerto Rico is very sorely out of date, leading to [reports that show, for example, Puerto Rico's COVID-19 positive test rate at 100%](https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/testing/testing-positivity) which then [get picked up by the press](https://www.metro.pr/pr/noticias/2020/07/02/puerto-rico-tiene-la-mayor-tasa-de-casos-positivos-de-coronavirus-en-estados-unidos.html).

I have been manually compiling a set of the official data that has been available. The official reports linked below are shared with some journalists by the Department of Health, with no appreciable schedule. These journalists tweet images of these reports out, which I have collected and copied their data into a CSV (also linked) over at my repo for my Puerto Rico data project: 

* https://github.com/sacundim/covid-19-puerto-rico

Insomuch as it is required I grant permission for you to use my CSVs (which I understand are facts and therefore not copyrightable anyway).

* [CSV file with data from all of the below](https://github.com/sacundim/covid-19-puerto-rico/blob/master/assets/data/PuertoRico-bioportal.csv)
* [Bio Portal report dated June 30, with data up to June 29](https://github.com/sacundim/covid-19-puerto-rico/blob/master/assets/source_material/2020-06-29/2020-06-29_bioportal.jpg)
* [Bio Portal report dated June 15, with data up to June 12](https://github.com/sacundim/covid-19-puerto-rico/blob/master/assets/source_material/2020-06-12/2020-06-12_bioportal.jpeg)
* [Bio Portal report dated June 8, with data up to June 6](https://github.com/sacundim/covid-19-puerto-rico/blob/master/assets/source_material/2020-06-06/2020-06-06_bioportal.jpeg)
* [Bio Portal report dated May 29, with data up to May 28](https://github.com/sacundim/covid-19-puerto-rico/blob/master/assets/source_material/2020-05-28/2020-05-28_bioportal.jpeg)
* [Bio Portal report dated May 23, with data up to May 21](https://github.com/sacundim/covid-19-puerto-rico/blob/master/assets/source_material/2020-05-21/2020-05-21_bioportal.jpeg)

While there is no evident path to automating the capture of this data, even a small one-time manual update to your numbers would likely avoid some modest amount of public misinformation.

title: [CO] PCL Historicals and WS2
body:
Starting [May 15](https://covidtracking.com/screenshots/CO/CO-20200515-182911.png), CO reports four different numbers about deaths: "deaths among cases," confirmed/probable breakdowns for "deaths among cases," and "deaths due to COVID-19." Deaths among cases captures information about all deaths in probable or confirmed COVID cases (e.g. determined by testing data for confirmed, syndromic or epidemiological evidence for probable), while "deaths due to COVID-19" tracks cases where COVID is listed on the death certificate.

Right now, we fill out our columns like this:
Deaths (confirmed+probable): "deaths among cases"
Deaths (confirmed): "deaths among cases (confirmed)"
Deaths (probable): "deaths among cases (probable"

However, to maintain consistency with other states (e.g. ND) that provide data about whether COVID was the _cause of death_ , we do not want to track "deaths among cases" but "deaths due to COVID-19," which tracks death certificate data. Hence for May 15 onward, we are going to switch to:

Deaths (confirmed+probable): "deaths due to COVID 19"
Deaths (confirmed): no data (since "deaths due to COVID-19" is not broken down to confirmed/probable)
Deaths (probable): "no data (since "deaths due to COVID-19" is not broken down to confirmed/probable)

We will add back the data for "deaths among cases (confirmed)" at a later date when we add a column for deaths w/ positive lab tests but not necessarily COVID as a cause of death on a death certificate.

title: [MN Historicals] Data since May increasingly differs from official.

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
Minnesota has gradually changed its reporting methods since roughly May 1st to putting interim data in its data tables and updating it as the data is confirmed. They also have changed positive results to representing the date collected. As a result, the data in the COVID Tracking Project since that date almost always disagrees at least a little bit with the official figures, and in some cases is wildly wrong, for example the numbers reported June 15-16:

COVID Tracking Project
June 13: 9658 tested, 2 positive, 9 deaths
June 14: 0 tested, 6 positive, 15 deaths

MN Department of Health
(https://www.health.state.mn.us/diseases/coronavirus/situation.html#testing, https://www.health.state.mn.us/diseases/coronavirus/situation.html#cases)
June 13: 9802 tested, 153 positive, 9 deaths 
June 14: 5019 tested, 148 positive, 15 deaths

To correct this, an update to the data tables is needed, and a new method of adding daily results needs to be used:
 1. Use the Testing and Cases data tables from the Department of Health to overwrite current historical data for testing and cases and test totals, excepting the previous 7 days before the current date. 
2.  Each day, update the most recent week's data for cases and tests (total and daily) from the revised data tables on the Minnesota Department of Health site.
3. Get the most recent data from the "daily update" at the top of the page after 11am CST and the Testing Data table or working backward from the day-over-day cumulative total.

I understand this is rather laborious. I'll help any way I can.

title: [ND] PCL Historicals and WS2
body: Deaths include several different data points, such as _"deaths due to COVID-19", "deaths where COVID-19 is not the primary cause", and "pending death records"._ We should consider "deaths due to COVID-19" as confirmed, and add the remaining values - **"pending death records", "deaths where COVID-19 is not the primary cause" and "deaths of individuals presumed positive" to obtain probables.** In WS2, we're reporting the total - number of individuals who tested positive and died from any cause while infected with COVID-19 - as our confirmed value. We should only be reporting "deaths due to covid-19" as our confirmed.

title: [Data Quality] Milestone IV: Change Total Test Resuts from Calculation to Direct number
body:
Changing totalTestResults column to stop calculating from pos+neg and instead use a direct totals value.

- [ ] Analyze [states identified by script where there are gaps](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1G_enjvPFG2CUAFiAGpeg-V0lKIdB6L5aDz2-GeiRrP4/edit#gid=0) in `Total Tests (PCR)` or `Total PCR Tests (People)`
- [ ] Check other states to ensure they have no gaps.
- [ ] Switch API from using pos+neg to using whichever total test figure is available.

Note: While #500 will affect the values of `Total Tests (PCR)` and `Total PCR Tests (People)`, we plan to launch this before it because of the importance of correcting the negative effects of pos+neg on data quality.

title: [Data Quality] Capture current values and fill in historicals for probable cases in DE spreadsheet
body:
**Target Date:** 8/1
**Overview:** Start explicitly recording probable cases during daily data entry shifts and backfill historical values.
**Contribution to milestone:** This issue will enable us to expose probable cases explicitly in the API/public spreadsheet, enabling better communication when we switch to confirmed+neg instead of pos+neg.
**Other benefits:** better understanding of probables (whether they are indeed pos-confirmed)
**Potential challenges:** We are hoping that the probables equal Positives (confirmed+probable) - Positive Cases (PCR) in all states, but if this is not the case we may need to do more digging.
**Editorial:** None

- [x] Add an explicit Cases (Probable) column to worksheet2. Begin collecting it in daily DE shifts.
- [ ] Create a sanity checking spreadsheet that checks whether Positives (confirmed+probable) - Positive Cases (PCR) matches our recorded probables values
- [ ] Backfill probables by using the calculation or other backfill sources if needed. File GH issues for any complicated states.

title: [Data Quality] Backfill timeseries for total testing in as many states as possible
body:
**Target Date:** TBD
**Overview**: Fill in historicals for total PCR tests by specimens and people in all states where it is available to enable drawing directly from it for as many states as possible in our new totals column. Prefer testing encounters over unique people where both are available, but do not launch extensive investigations into testing encounters vs. people where the language is unclear.
**Contribution to Milestone**: This will enable the main goal of the milestone—providing explicit totals for every state, one by one, instead of using positive+negative. We cannot do that without having these values filled in.
**Other Benefits**: Improved historical totals.
**Potential Challenges**: It is really hard to backfill these figures and to make decisions about which kind of historical dating to use, as well as how to sync it up with our pre-existing timeseries.
Some states may provide both testing encounters and unique people historical timeseries. We should try to capture both in our historical updates, even if not in our States Daily capture.
DQ and backfill will be working on this from two different angles—backfill from the angle of our communication with that state, and DQ from the angle of our handling in worksheet2. We will need to ensure they coordinate.
We will need to perform outreach to states to clarify "Unclear" totals.
**Editorial**: None at this step. We will run the editorial content on the change when we surface it in the totals columns.

**DQ:**
- [x] Do an annotation run on Specimens vs. People for Totals, skipping questions about  encounters vs. unique people (see questions in Annotations below, which also proposes splitting SVP into three tabs, similar to recent partitioning of PCL into two tabs). 
- [ ] For each state with wrong worksheet2 handling that is not currently reporting "unclear" totals:
   - [ ] Fix worksheet2 handling
   - [ ] File GH Issue investigating the total tests history and log in a central GH issue to track our investigations in all states. 
   - [ ] Fix the issue, with assist from backfill as needed
- [ ] For any unclear totals states:
    - [ ] Reach out to them to clarify whether their totals are specimens vs people. 
    - [ ] Pass on the information from states that respond to backfill team to file GH issues.
    - [ ] For states that do not respond, stop tracking unclear totals.

**Backfill:**
- [ ] For each state, in order of priority depending on our communication with that state:
   - [ ] File GH Issue investigating the total tests history, with assist from DQ as needed, and log in a central GH issue to track our investigations in all states
   - [ ] Fix the issue by filling in the timeseries

title: Tweaks to the public-facing spreadsheet

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
The main [data spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/2/d/e/2PACX-1vRwAqp96T9sYYq2-i7Tj0pvTf6XVHjDSMIKBdZHXiCGGdNC0ypEU9NbngS8mxea55JuCFuua1MUeOj5/pubhtml#) is an excellent single-page source of information, but could be cleaned up a bit.

I wasn't sure which repo to add this to, including it here since it's just spreadsheet update.   
A dash of suggestions:

== Tab headers
**States Current** - lowercase Current  
**US current** - fine  
**States daily** 4 pm ET - remove time  
**US daily** 4 pm ET   
**States** - "States notes" would be clearer  

== Header row within each tab
**States current**
Close to the ideal -- no extra vertical space in the header, double-thick lines indicating frozen first col and row.  Column nitpicks:   
* Positive - "Positive cases"
* Negative - "Negative cases"
* Pending - drop this column. 
* Last update - "Source last updated"
* Check time  - drop this column; confusing (and not included in States daily).  If it must be included, rename for clarity, to something like "Source last checked for updates"

**US current**  
Reduce the whitespace in the header row.  Freeze that row (double-thick line below)  
* Add "Date" column as the first column, as with _US daily_
* Add "Last update" column - add a timestamp column w/ the time this was updated from the previous day

**States daily** 
Reduce whitespace in the header. Drop the "4pm" in the title - that's not always accurate.  Freeze the header row and first two columns.
* State - make narrower to match _States current_
* Pending - remove column
* Deaths - make narrower

**US daily** 
Reduce whitespace in the header. Freeze the first two columns.
* Positive, Negative, Pending - "Positive cases", "Negative cases", "Pending cases"  [once tests/cases is normalized]
* Add "Last update" column, as with _US current_, for the full timestamp.

**States** 
Make header row unbold, and centered.  Freeze first column.
* Make URL columns a bit narrower, and Notes column a bit wider.

title: Negative values and field definitions

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
Hi, I am using the data from https://covidtracking.com/api/v1/states/daily.csv

I noticed that the following columns contain negative values
deathIncrease, hospitalizedIncrease, negativeIncrease, positiveIncrease, totalTestResultsIncrease

which may be an error or I may be misunderstanding the definition. Take deathIncrease. It is defined as "Increase from the day before". It doesn't say what the source column is, so I suppose it's the column "death", which is defined as "Total cumulative number of people that have died." I don't see how that can possibly decrease, so has to give rise to a negative increase (known resurrection events did not take place on the dates considered or on US territory). With hospitalizedIncrease, there is uncertainty on the source column, which could be hospitalizedCurrently, -Cumulative or just hospitalized.  Depending on which one is the one, negative increases are a possibility. For negative, positive and totalTestResults, again I don't see how a test can become undone after it was done (maybe retracted or invalidated?) or a person un-tested. Could you please clarify? The number of rows affected is modest, between 10 and 21 for the listed fields. Thanks

title: [SC Historicals] Cases when SC reporting seems to not match CTP reporting

labels.name: stale

body:
From Front https://app.frontapp.com/open/msg_dlyhb2p

[South_Carolina_out.xlsx](https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/issues/files/4696620/South_Carolina_out.xlsx)

Here is the Excel file for South Carolina. The individual numbers are colored. Black is for when the numbers have been verified through the daily state reports. Blue is for when I could not find a copy of the daily report and relied on the numbers from The COVID Tracking Project. Orange is when I verified the numbers through a tertiary source. This is almost always the Twitter feed for the state's Department of Health. Red is for when I verified the number through the state's daily reports and those numbers did not correspond to the one presented in The COVID Tracking Project.

The red numbers can be compared to the daily state screenshots. Sometimes the variance is minor. In South Carolina, The COVID Tracking Project had several instances where the numbers were repeated from date to date when the numbers did change in the daily screenshots.

title: Utah issues reported on covid-tracking-data repo
body:
Someone made a PR in covid-tracking-data (https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/covid-tracking-data/pull/73) to fix some Utah data, pasting their PR description here too:

"This branch contains manually repaired data files with updates for two data events related to the state of Utah:

Hospitalization data for May 22 and 23 was somehow scraped incorrectly from the state's website. The total cumulative hospitalizations should be 660 and 676 as retrieved from https://coronavirus.utah.gov/case-counts/ on May 23 and 24 around 11:30 am Mountain.
The state's website had an outage on May 19, which caused the data for that day to be a duplicate of the May 18 data. I manually reconstructed the May 19 data from local news reporting which captured the true data reported later in the day. I also adjusted the case increment columns for May 20 to be consistent with the May 19 manual edits."

(I'm not merging PRs fixing data in covid-tracking-data, just going to link to them in issues in this repo)

title: [UT Historical] Repair data for May 19, 22, 23
body:
The state of Utah had an outage on May 19 which caused that day's data to be a duplicate of May 18.

Hospitalization data for May 22 and 23 was incorrect with respect to totals on the state's site as retrieved around 11:30 am on May 23 and May 24, respectively.

This pull request documents the required repairs. I realize that directly incorporating the pull request into `covid-tracking-data` may not be the best repair strategy, but it served as a convenient way to convey the required changes and allowed me to continue plotting without strange aberrations.

https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/covid-tracking-data/pull/73

body: > Looking at the “Positive” data for Texas I’m seeing two likely errors. First on, 5/11/20 and 5/12/20 the number of reported cases was 39,869 for both days. This would mean that no new cases occurred of 5/12/20 at a time when the daily average number of new cases in the two weeks before and after 5/11/20 was 1,256. title: API docs should mention the by-state nuance in "positive"
body:
I noticed at https://covidtracking.com/api that the "positive" field e.g. for StateData is described as "Total cumulative positive test results."

Based on resolution of issue #308 it sounds like there is some flex in that "positive test results" restriction.

So I request the description be enhanced to include various other conditions which are allowed to be counted in this field so that it's known to people doing modeling based on it. (e.g. predicting onset date.)

e.g. if resolution of #308 is correct, then include at least two caveats in "positive." These are based on Idaho DHW's definition of their "probable" count which is currently a component of COVID Tracking Project's "positive" for that state:
- includes symptomatic people with epidemiologic risk factors (but were not tested)
- positives may be reclassified as negative (subtracted from positive) if laboratory testing is performed later indicating negative

I also suggest the test type be qualified, e.g. molecular amplification (vs. otherwise.)

I don't have visibility beyond Idaho so I don't know what other qualifications might exist, but I think the above are probably relevant for most states.

title: CA 4/1 to current 5/17 - Data is off by one day from official CA press releases
body:
Starting on March 30th, the California reporting structure changed, displaying a “California COVID-19 By the Numbers” infographic. This image reports the data for the day according to the end-of-day values from the previous day. The CTP starts recording this data as a primary source on April 2nd, except it enters the data on the day the graphic is published, not the day referenced in the graphic. So the [April 2nd graphic](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-041.aspx) matches the CTP data for April 2nd, however the graphic lists them as end-of-day numbers for April 1st.

Need to shift **all** CA numbers so that they reflect CA's "Numbers as of $date", not the press release date ($date+1). Day forward recording needs to be enter numbers for $date in the actual matching day as well.

This change is important for consistency and modeling.

For March fixes (which include similar off-by-one errors, among others), please see:
#432 
#431 

@thaynedye
@dcmoyer

title: CA 3/18 - 3/31 - Data doesn't match CA official press releases
body:
Quite a few issues here. Some typos in data entry and a running off-by-a-day issue.

Because the screenshots are inconsistent, I reference the current official [CA press release archive](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/New-Release-2020.aspx) instead.

California started reporting total and pending test numbers on March 18th, so I'm including those here too. The CTP March CA numbers have "N/A" values for Pending through 3/23. It's unclear where some of the earlier Total test numbers come from.

[March 18 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-027.aspx) "As of March 18, 2020, 6 p.m. PDT"
**3/18 should have 675 Positives instead of 611.**
**3/18 should have 16 Deaths instead of 13.** 
**3/18 should have 6,300 Total [Tests] instead of 8,592.** 
**3/18 should have 10,000 Pending [Tests] instead of N/A.** 
"At least 6,300 results have been received and another 10,000+ are pending."

[March 19 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-028.aspx) "As of March 19, 2020, 6 p.m. PDT"
**3/19 should have 1,006 Positives instead of 924.**
**3/19 should have 19 Deaths instead of `18.** 
**3/19 should have 11,487 Total [Tests] instead of 9,711.** This is currently an off-by-one for the 20th.
**3/19 should have 11,700 Pending [Tests] instead of N/A.** 

[March 20 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-029.aspx) "As of March 20, 2020, 6 p.m. PDT"
**3/20 should have 1,224 Positives instead of 1,063.**
**3/20 should have 23 Deaths instead of 20.** 
**3/20 should have 12,528 Total [Tests] instead of 9,711.** This is currently an off-by-one for the 21st.
**3/20 should have 12,700 Pending [Tests] instead of N/A.** 

**Note: CA daily reporting cutoff moves up four hours from 6 p.m. to 2 p.m. PDT between 3/20 and 3/21. 

[March 21 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-030.aspx) "As of March 21, 2020, 2 p.m. PDT"
**3/21 should have 1,468 Positives instead of 1,279.**
**3/21 should have 27 Deaths instead of 24.** 
**3/21 should have 13,467 Total [Tests] instead of 12,528.** This is currently an off-by-one for the 22nd.
**3/21 should have 12,700 Pending [Tests] instead of N/A.** 

[March 22 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-031.aspx) "As of March 22, 2020, 2 p.m. PDT"
**3/22 should have 1,733 Positives instead of 1,536.**
**3/22 correctly lists deaths at 27.** 
**3/22 should have 14,317 Total [Tests] instead of 12,840.** This is currently an off-by-one for the 23rd.
**3/22 should have 12,100 Pending [Tests] instead of N/A.** 

[March 23 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-032.aspx) "As of March 23, 2020, 2 p.m. PDT" This is currently an off-by-one for the 24th.
**3/23 should have 2,102 Positives instead of 1,733.**
**3/23 should have 40 Deaths instead of 27.**
**3/23 should have 15,554 Total [Tests] instead of 14,300.** 
**3/23 correctly lists 12,100 Pending [Tests].** 

[March 24 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-033.aspx) "As of March 24, 2020, 2 p.m. PDT" This is currently an off-by-one for the 25th.
**3/24 should have 2,535 Positives instead of 2,102.**
**3/24 should have 53 Deaths instead of 40.**
**3/24 should have 18,276 Total [Tests] instead of 15,554.** 
**3/24 should have 48,600 Pending [Tests] instead of 12,100.** 

[March 25 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-034.aspx) "As of March 25 2020, 2 p.m. PDT" This is currently an off-by-one for the 26th.
**3/25 should have 3,006 Positives instead of 2,355.** This is both off-by-one and a typo of "2,535".
**3/25 should have 65 Deaths instead of 53.**
**3/25 should have 20,386 Total [Tests] instead of 18,276.** 
**3/25 should have 57,400 Pending [Tests] instead of 48,600.** 

[March 26 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-035.aspx) "As of March 26 2020, 2 p.m. PDT" This is currently an off-by-one for the 27th.
**3/26 should have 3,801 Positives instead of 3,006.** 
**3/26 should have 78 Deaths instead of 65.**
**3/26 should have 23,480 Total [Tests] instead of 20,386.** Current number is wrong, not just off-by-one.
**3/26 should have 65,000 Pending [Tests] instead of 57,400.** 

[March 27 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-036.aspx) "As of March 27 2020, 2 p.m. PDT" 
**3/27 should have 4,643 Positives instead of 3,879.** Current number is wrong, not just off-by-one.
**3/27 should have 101 Deaths instead of 78.**
**3/27 should have 25,192 Total [Tests] instead of 21,259.** 
**3/27 should have 64,400 Pending [Tests] instead of 57,400.** 

March 28 state data is missing for positives and deaths. The next CA state data report is for the 29th. Unclear where CTP data comes from. Treat as non-reporting day for positives and deaths.
CA notes "***This week’s cumulative testing numbers are lower than last week due to an inadvertent over-reporting error discovered by one of the private labs."
[March 28 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-037.aspx) "As of March 28 2020, 2 p.m. PDT" 
**3/28 should have 27,251 Total [Tests] instead of 21,259.** 
**3/28 should have 56,550 Pending [Tests] instead of 57,400.** 

[March 29 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-037.aspx) "As of March 29 2020, 2 p.m. PDT". This report includes March 28th's total and pending test numbers. There are no reported total and pending numbers for March 29. Treat as non-reporting day.
**3/29 should have 5,763 Positives instead of 5,708.** Current number is wrong, not just off-by-one.
**3/29 should have 135 Deaths instead of 123.**

[March 30 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-038.aspx). CA stopped reporting a time cutoff starting with the March 31 press release w/ March 30 data.
**3/30  should have 6,932 Positives instead of 6,447.**
**3/30  should have 150 Deaths instead of 133.**
**3/30  should have 28,704 Total [Tests] instead of 26,996.** 
**3/30  should have 57,400 Pending [Tests] instead of 64,400.** 

[March 31 state data](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-039.aspx). 
**3/30  should have 8,155 Positives instead of 7,482.**
**3/30  should have 171 Deaths instead of 153.**
**3/30  should have 31,038 Total [Tests] instead of 29,254.** 
**3/30  should have 59,100 Pending [Tests] instead of 57,400.** 

Off-by-a-day errors aside, it makes sense to use official state reported confirmed case and death numbers for a date when those are higher than current CTP reported values. It is unlikely the state is making up higher positive case and death counts.

@thaynedye
@dcmoyer

title: AK 4/13 - Incorrect data - Negative new tests and total negatives
body:

Cannot have negative 208 new tests or a decrease in total negatives.

The [official state records](https://coronavirus-response-alaska-dhss.hub.arcgis.com/datasets/covid-tests-dataset) show 67 new tests on the day that the state reached 277 cumulative positives. This number was added to the previous day's total and the negatives were calculated from that.

title: Data Quality - date reported vs. date of illness onset
body: From the support request: 1. your case counts are the same for april 25-27. This is not reflected on the washington DOH site, which is where you claim to get your data from. I suspect this is because you (or the DOH site) had a retrieval failure on those days, but that failure should not be reflected in historical data. 2. more generally, your historical data for each day appears to be based on the value of the total case numbers retrieved in the snapshot on that day, from the Washington DOH site. But there are external factors affecting the DOH's incoming flow of case reports, and when they add cases to the site, they assign each case to the day of illness onset. Your data would be much more meaningful if you reported out historical data by date of illness onset, rather than date that the DOH put the case up on their site. I assume this would apply to other states as well. The net result is that (in my opinion) your data for washington are currently misleading. If there's any way that I can help to fix this, please let me know. Note from GG/support desk: this seems like a big ask and not sure if it is even doable. Let me know. [Front conversations](https://app.frontapp.com/open/top_23xsh)

title: New York State and NYC Data

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
May 7 Death Count reported at 20,828 
May 6 Death Count reported at 19,877  

This indicates 951 deaths which exceeds the highest number of deaths reported at 799.  There were no reports in the news in NYC or State that this had occurred.  Could someone verify the counts or is this just NYS reclassifying deaths from an older time period because of the issue with nursing homes and adult care facilities.

Also is there a way to add current hospitalization to the excel sheets at the state level.  This is critical tracking data.

The more significant data analysis is not the total, rather the change from current day to prior day and the measurement of rate of change.  For example NYS shows an overall rate of 28% for those tested as being positive.  Yet since April 1 the rate of testing positive to new tests was at 15% and dropping each day as more tests are completed.  Currently at 8%. 

This is critical information for researchers to offer opinions on.  Is the virus weakening or is herd immunity beginning to occur.

Given that NYC is considered the epicenter the quality of the data available from the City is lacking.  All historical data must be updated daily in order to develop any meaningful analysis.  The data clearly indicates peak deaths were on April 7, but the historical data (one must update numbers for cases, hospitalization, deaths and total cases each day from the beginning) is changed every day which limits any meaningful predictive analysis.  Testing Positive and Hospitalizations historical data also changes everyday.  A one or two day lag in understandable but updating data that is over 14 days old skews analysis and begs the question of overall data reliability.

Logistics are not just about PPE and hospital rooms for this pandemic.  Accurate and timely data is essential for the scientists and researchers to understand how this virus spreads and communities are impacted.  Contact tracing will not work if the data is not accurate and timely.  Nor will rate of spread analysis.

The IHME projections are estimating higher rates of deaths and cases in NY.  If their underlying data is not being updated and models recalibrated the results will be misleading to government planners and hospital administrators.

I have saved a new file every 3 days so there are historical files that can be used as a baseline to understand the changes to the NYC data.  

[coronavirus 5-10-2020.xlsx](https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/issues/files/4610417/coronavirus.5-10-2020.xlsx)
 

Finally are the serology test results counted as part of the new tests.

Thank you.

title: Small format requests for public data table

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
A few small tweaks would make the public tables more uniform and easier to parse.

**Overall**
- Title: "Coronavirus numbers by state" --> "COVID-19 data, state and national"
- For all date fields, standardize the date format (e.g., settle on yyyy/mm/dd or m/d/yyyy)

**Tabs**
- States: make the current header two lines high (add line breaks before parens).  Add another row above it w/ a description ("Detailed source descriptions for each state"). Add margin to State col, center it.  Add Data Quality Grade on the right.
- US daily: compress top margin in header,  freeze left column, add a little padding to it.  
- States daily: narrow State col, center.  margin for date.  compress top margin in header.    drop Pending column :)  
- US current: add current date as left-most col. 
- States current: add current date as left-most col.  center State column.  include Data Quality Grade

title: Georgia ‘A’ grade should be revisited. They recently changed reporting methodology to deceive public
body: Please reconsider your grade A rating for Georgia. At the end of April, they changed their reporting, and it is now very deceptive. They’ve started reporting cases as the date where patient exhibited symptoms OR the date they first requested medical care OR the date of the test...so that past totals are constantly changing and the curve always appears to be going down. This is ridiculous. It would make sense if they always reported on one of the three dates, but they’ve created a chaotic arrangement of data where past numbers are constantly in flux and it’s nearly impossible to track.

title: Twitter 7-day average line is incorrect
body:
All the bar charts on Twitter purport to show a "rolling 7-day average" line. I'm not quite sure how you're taking that average, but it seems wrong.

For example, look at the deaths data from today (Saturday):
![deaths](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EXmsSjCU8AYqFRF?format=jpg&name=small)

On the left it takes until Mar 31 for the line **not** to be above the bars, so the line must be averaging in data from later dates, but since it hits the bar on Mar 31, it must also be averaging in earlier dates, since the 7 days after that are all higher.

However, if I plot the average of a 7-day window centering it on the date in question, I don't get your line. I think I get it if I plot a moving 15-day window, but yours still seems smoothed a bit more. So, I think what  you're really doing is plotting a rolling 15-day average, not 7. My version:
![Rplot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/615115/81486447-23e05000-9255-11ea-940c-11174d9c3553.png)

PS I'd suggest a 7-day trailing average, so you always have complete data for each point on the line. Right now, you're having to supply data somehow for each of the last 7 days of the line since there are no later dates to roll in.

R code for my plot, using your data as `covid_usa`:
```r
df <- filter(covid_usa, date >= as.Date ("2020-03-01"))
ggplot(df) +
    scale_color_manual(values = c("gold")) +
    labs(title = "US Daily Deaths", x = NULL, y = "Count") +
    theme(legend.position = "NONE" ) +
    scale_x_date(breaks = "3 day", minor_breaks = "1 day", limits = c(as.Date("2020-03-01"), NA)) +
    scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 270)) +
    geom_col(aes(y = deathIncrease, x = date), size = 1, color = "blue", fill = "blue", width = .5) +
    geom_line(aes(color = "Rolling 15-day average", x = date, y = rollapply(deathIncrease, 15, FUN = "mean", align = "center", fill = NA) ), size = 1 )

```

title: Should Georgia still be graded with an A?
body:
Georgia recently changed the way they were reporting confirmed cases - they are now retroactively adding cases to the "date of symptom onset" or the "date the test was taken" if date of symptom onset is not available.  They say on the website that this means that within a 14-day window the case count may not be correct since they are continuing to add cases as their results come in (which is understandable and I like the transparency).  

However, they are still showing current numbers on their "COVID-19 cases over time" chart, which means that to a lay audience it looks like Georgia's cases have decreased RAPIDLY within the last two weeks - which may not be the case. Considering all of these factors, I wanted to see if Georgia's data quality should still be an A?

title: why change the columns?
body:
I appreciate what you guys are doing.

I will just note that I think it's helpful once you have columns established to leave them where they are.

I think next time I may choose a different data source, because I've run into a time-wasters.

First, and least troublesome, the time series are in backwards order, so have to be reversed for charting.  Secondly the dates are not readable by Excel (have to be parsed even though Excel can read a wide variety of standard date formats).  And as I [mentioned before](https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/issues/issues/210), data for hospitalizedCurrently and hospitalizedCumulative were for awhile swapped (now are switched back), so Currently was larger than Cumulative.

But this is maybe the biggest glitch.  I don't see why once you have a data file going, you need to change the columns.  Yesterday the file reads into Excel with Column O being "death", and today it reads in with that column being "hash".

That's the [state data](https://covidtracking.com/api/v1/states/daily.csv) from [the API](https://covidtracking.com/api).

And the [US data](https://covidtracking.com/api/v1/us/daily.csv) file still has "death" in Column O, so now the two files are inconsistent with each other.

It's both easier and faster computationally to just read Column O rather than to actually search for specific text, and usually that works.  In this case, it's obvious enough that the hash is not even a number no less the number of deaths.  But were it a different column with similar-type numbers, say "recovered" then it would be harder to notice right away.

Column Q used to be "total" -- tests -- so that's at least an integer so would plug into analysis and produce wrong results.

The "total" column header name also indicates another little glitch, which is that they are not descriptive.  Why have a column titled "total"?  Total what?  The "positive" and "negative" columns are at the beginning of the spreadsheet and it's not clear that they are what would be totaled there.  The total column isn't even entirely necessary.  Presumably anyone who is analyzing this data is able to add two columns, although this does save some computation time.

The column-swapping though means that as with the date we have to do this the hard way, make sure that you haven't moved things around.  However, even if you have, you might put the data in the wrong column as with the hospitalized before.

I have VBA automatically reverse the time series order when I paste it, but in general, it's easier to work with time series data that is in incremental order.  It's possible to overcome any hurdles.  It just sort of wastes time and risks unnecessary glitches.

So you are springing a few unnecessary traps for people here, I think.

I'm not sure why "death" is all the way over in Column O (now Column Q) anyway.  This is probably the single-most-important statistic.  But once it's there, maybe just leave it there -- and certainly don't push it even farther away from the first column.

Anyway, good job overall with all of the tracking.  I think this is very important.  And all things considered I think the glitches have been minimal.

Dan

title: Important measure is missing
body:
Hello,

It shouldn't be hard to add the following measurement:
corona deaths / 1M population
This measurement will show completely different global picture on the pandemic.
With this measure correlation with http://www.bcgatlas.org/ would be complete.
For example Ecuador posses highest death rate in South America and it is the only country without BCG in this continent.

Thanks.

title: Puerto Rico does not deserved the D grades
body:
Last report of Puerto Rico coroner office NCF (NEGOCIADO DE CIENCIAS FORENSES): "Hasta el día de hoy se han recibido 64 casos sospechosos de coronavirus para autopsias, de los cuales 53 han arrojado resultados negativos y siete están pendientes de resultado".
"To date, 64 suspected cases of coronavirus have been received for autopsy, of which 53 have yielded negative results and seven are pending results."
This is the proof the hospitals in Puerto Rico diagnose the disease without any tests; by symptoms only. But Puerto Rico suffer not only from coronavirus. Puerto Rico has the same time Dengue, influenza, Cystic fibrosis etc diseases and illnesses with the same symptoms. But influenza for example has medications which can cure patients. But hospitals in Puerto Rico did not provide influenza tests. Doctors leave the patients in hospitals died without any medical help. After patients died coroner provide coronavirus tests but not influenza or Dengue tests. 53 people was not infected by coronavirus. But coroners by autopsy did not find the reason of death of 53 people. 

Puerto Rico even does not deserved grade F. Puerto Rico kill patients in his hospitals. 

Today in Puerto Rico was registered 97 deaths. By report of coroners 64 - 53 = 11 patients had positive coronavirus tests. How and why died 97 - 11 = 86 patients? No answers. Seems to be the all records in Puerto Rico are false.

NCF office continue to use protocols from 2017 after hurricane Maria.

title: new Florida site available that adds Non-Resident data to Resident data
body:
Florida is currently only showing Resident data instead of data from both Residents and Non-Residents. The latter is now available.

[2] should redirect to get data from [3] instead of [4]. Then
A. Residents and non-residents could be included and
B. Florida would become "Machine Readable" -- the scorecard is showing this is not currently machine readble and this site is via a straightforward html scrape.

According to [1] "We attempt to report numbers that reflect individuals who are isolated and recovering in the state. Most states report this number, but due to cruise ship quarantines and other movements of individuals, some states (like Florida and Montana) report several categories of confirmed cases." The non-Resident category should be added to the Resident category, and this data is now available.

[1] https://covidtracking.com/about-data/faq#are-you-accounting-for-only-residents
[2] https://covidtracking.com/data/state/florida
[3] https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/
[4] https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/96dd742462124fa0b38ddedb9b25e429/

title: Proposal: Add stale bot to this issue queue
body:
Because the large number of issues, may I propose adding Stalebot to this issue tracker? We could then:

Flag issues with *no* activity for X days with a "stale" label
If an issue with "stale" is inactive for X days more, it is closed
You can add a label like "not stale" to make sure the bot doesn't touch it.

title: PA's Positive counts for April 22-23 may be incorrect
body:
Comparing the data shown in the Positive column [here](https://covidtracking.com/data/state/pennsylvania#historical) to the numbers shown in the accompanying screen shots, it appears the Positive column represents Pennsylvania's total case counts, including both confirmed and probable cases.

However, on April 22nd, the table uses the figure 35045, which includes only confirmed cases, according to the screen shots, not probables. The correct figure that includes probables, and would match the other dates, is 35684. Both numbers appear on the screen shot. It appears the site just used the wrong one.

Then the next day, April 23rd, the table shows a Positive value of 36647. This doesn't seem to appear on any of the screen shots for that day. The figure that does is 37053. So I think the Positive value for April 23rd also needs correcting.

title: JHU Comparison Runs / Conflation?
body:
Hi all, I run [covid-19-tools](https://github.com/mezcalhead/covid-19-tools) which is more of a python library for working with covid-data in object oriented structures.  It does a good job of processing JHU's data as well.  One of the things we can do quickly is run the state-by-state comparison, just after midnight EST.

In the following, the first number is JHU's state death count (summed up from the county level).  The second number is the death count from Covid19Tracking's JSON API.  Third number is the delta.  As you can see there are some very good perfect matches here, but NY is obscenely off (JHU problem).

I'm willing to look at calibrating the models a little bit. In fact, calibrating the JHU county level data to the Covid19Tracking because if we're interested in the best possible data, we ought to be synthesizing as many sources as possible.

labels.name: stale

body: Prior to, and including 4/28, the Positives for Ohio were taking the "Confirmed Cases" on Ohio's Dashboard. See tweet from Gov Dewine here: https://twitter.com/GovMikeDeWine/status/1255204105015955457 However, on 4/29, the Positives were taken from the 'Total Cases' and not 'Confirmed Cases' (see attached picture). This made it look like a tremendous jump in cases for Ohio from 4/28 to 4/29. To fix this, it either makes sense to change 4/29 Positives to 'Confirmed Cases' or to change every other date before 4/29 to 'Total Cases' for the sake of day-to-day consistency.

title: Massachusetts Historical Deaths seem to have changed
body:
The number of deaths due to coronavirus disease seemed low to me over the weekend and so I went back to some historical data and it seems as if there has been a complete restatement of deaths by date in MA.  I doubt this was intentional.  

For example, the MA history shows that MA suffered its 1000th death on April 12 yet this report from the local NPR affiliate, and a number of other sources, cites April 15. https://www.wbur.org/commonhealth/2020/04/15/coronavirus-1000-deaths-massachusetts

On that date, the COVID Tracking States Daily report shows MA went over 1500 deaths.  This constrasts with the unbelievably (unfortunately) small 22 deaths over the entire weekend.

The historical Daily tracking reports used to match much more closely to figures reported in the press.  Finally, here are a few days as they were posted on Friday on GitHub.  The Wednesday number of total deaths from last Friday's data shows 2,182 (see below).  That number currently on GitHub is now 2,597.

From Friday, April 24.

title: Idaho's "positive" started including presumed cases 4/17, so possibly off by up to 9.8% as of 5/17
body:
The report for Idaho at https://covidtracking.com/data as of 4/26 states "as of 4/24, Idaho separately reports both probable and confirmed cases". That's not correct; Idaho DHW started reporting probable cases separately from confirmed (positive) cases on 4/9, and the number of cases shown on https://coronavirus.idaho.gov since 4/17 has been the **sum** of probable and confirmed/positive!

At the time I opened this issue the API documents stated "positive" is "Total cumulative positive test results", so I presume the data you're collecting as "positive" wasn't intended to include Idaho's probable counts.

You can see evidence of this in [screencaps](https://covidtracking.com/data/state/idaho#historical). Note the label, and what the label says going back through 4/17, 4/9, earlier.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1535656/80336420-701e9f80-8814-11ea-9773-567cd25810c1.png)

Idaho DHW's Tableau dashboard (which https://coronavirus.idaho.gov started linking to on 4/2) has the detailed data needed to fix this, in tooltips on this cumulative cases chart:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1535656/80322438-73993300-87e2-11ea-9b82-0ff88c9ae68c.png)

If the chart is ever removed, I have a copy of the data as far back as 4/9 I can provide.

title: Number of tests versus number of individuals tested

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body: Do we have any idea which, if any states, are tracking the number of separate individuals tested versus the number of total tests given? Without that, it is impossible to determine the actual number of people actually infected beyond those who are hospitalized.  We could extrapolate and say if hospitalization was needed in, say, 20% of positive cases, then multiply the total number of cumulative hospitla cases by 5 to get a ballpark number of infected, but we don't have usable hospital numbers from most states so that is not possible. The number of negative results is likewise misleading if thousands or tens of thousands of people have been tested multiple times, such as medical personnel.

Hello,

I am a public health graduate student at Zilber School of Public Health, and I have some questions specifically on the Wisconsin data.

I appreciate your time!

Lisa Blair

title: Reported death date versus actual death date
body:
There appears to be discrepancy in deaths per day between the reported date and the actual date. Part of this is timing and part might stem from the CDC April 14 update on "probable" deaths. For example, when NYC reported 3,338 "probable" deaths and states are now reporting previously unrecorded deaths outside of hospitals (nursing homes, etc) how are these being accounted for: on the day they are reported or on the prior dates when they occured? Or both depending on the data format?

For example Massachusetts includes a daily chart of daily and total deaths (see attached). The footnote reads: "*Counts on the trend chart do not match total number of deaths reported, as there is a several day lag in reporting by date of death." (https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-dashboard-april-21-2020/download).

The daily deaths are much lower than the deaths reported on the website and most data sources.
Are they waiting on the actual dates to be determined before adding them in a time-series? Is this the delay they are talking about?

title: Dates for Puerto Rico values one day ahead of official bulletins

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
Puerto Rico's Department of Health has been most days reporting new daily figures each morning in a bulletin that labels the data as being **as of the previous day**. But your website is instead reporting the same figures as of the day that the scraper picks them up, leading to an off-by-one day discrepancy between your data set and other sources that show Puerto Rico data, which I've seen has confused a few people.

I think there's nothing wrong with your website's semantics, it's just different, but I've seen this detail confuse a handful of people already and thus see this as a reasonable choice but one that ought to be documented.

Concrete example: here's an excerpt from the Puerto Rico Department of Health's most recent morning bulletin:

![Boletín 20 abril](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4076056/79925727-e7f16200-83ef-11ea-8c75-bc336fb55520.jpeg)

This bulletin was published on the morning of April 21, but it says that **as of April 20** ("Fecha de actualización de datos," i.e., date of data update) there were, cumulatively:

- 1,298 cases 
- 64 deaths
- 8,789 negative results
- 1,751 pending results
- 10 inconclusive results

The COVID Tracking Project data set is picking up these figures, but attributing them to **April 21**, the date that your scraper picks up the new numbers.

title: Hospitalizations figure should be 3x higher
body:
Your "Hospitalized – Cumulative" figure ([found here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/2/d/e/2PACX-1vRwAqp96T9sYYq2-i7Tj0pvTf6XVHjDSMIKBdZHXiCGGdNC0ypEU9NbngS8mxea55JuCFuua1MUeOj5/pubhtml#)) should probably be around 3x higher. It's currently at 82,879 while deaths are at 37,321, implying a hospitalizations-to-deaths ratio of 2.22. This is only a third of what [the IHME calculated](http://www.healthdata.org/sites/default/files/files/Projects/COVID/Estimation_update_041320.pdf) on the 13th using data from 23 states.

IHME aside, it's obvious that nowhere close to half of those being hospitalized are dying. Is it possible to either drastically improve this data or remove it altogether? It would be better to have no figure at all than one that's this far off.

Thanks for making this API!

Like many others, I've been using the API data in a Google Spreadsheet so I built a Sheets Add-on to make it easier to pull the data directly into a spreadsheet: https://github.com/acmeyer/sheets-covid-tracker

It allows users to pull it in as raw data, much like your existing Google Spreadsheet, but also allows users to pull specific data. For example, you can simply use `= GET_STATES_DATA("NY", "positive")` to get the latest number of positive cases for New York.

Anyway, I was going to release the add-on myself but thought it would be better as part of the official project since it would get a larger audience and can have more people contributing to it. I'm happy to help walk you through how to get it launched if that helps too.

Let me know if this is of any interest, and thanks again for doing this!

title: What constitutes a test?

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body: Currently (4/19/20) only 19.4% of tests (749203 of 3865864) are resulting positive. The fact that most people are being told that they need to be symptomatic to get tested in the first place makes this result highly questionable. Which leads me to two possible conclusions: either people who attempt to get tested (potentially by simply having their temperature read) but don't meet the classification of being symptomatic are then being included in the total testing and negative results figures being represented; or asymptomatic people with access (either via wealth, occupation, social position, or a combination thereof) are being granted special access to testing. I suspect the answer may be a combination of these two scenarios.

title: Show trajectories for reopening criteria
body:
This issue proposes changing the reporting format to maximize its usefulness to policy makers and citizens. A key decision for policy makers is the timing for the phases of reopening. The covidtracking reports should facilitate that. The same information is useful for citizens; by observing the data's trends, they can predict what policy makers are likely to do and arrange their personal decisions accordingly.

The Guidelines for Opening Up America Again use the following [criteria](https://www.whitehouse.gov/openingamerica/#criteria):

* Influenza-like illnesses (ILI)
* Covid-like syndromic cases
* Covid-19 cases
* Positive Covid-19 tests as a percent of total tests

As many of these quantities as possible should be shown. They should be shown as daily (not cumulative) quantities so that the presence or absence of the required downward trajectories is readily apparent. Each quantity should have a graph to help visualize the trajectory.

title: Standard GeoJSON format for the COVIDTracking API?

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
Hi, a great initiative you have for consolidating US COVID-19 data. I'm the author of the [CovidJSON](https://covidjson.org) initiative, a standards based GeoJSON data model for infection data. Our goal is to harmonize national and international data interchange of COVID-19 data as geospatial datasets, and to make it easier to collect, publish, analyze and visualize infection data across different data providers and uses.

Would you be interested in testing out the CovidJSON format as an output format for the COVIDTracking API, providing input for improving it, and, in case you like it, promoting it's use for the different COVID-19 stakeholders within US?

I have some live data samples from Finland at https://data.covidjson.org/ and some static examples at https://github.com/spatineo/covidjson/tree/master/examples

title: Historicals for VA (4/11 & 4/12)
body:
Some issues with VA data for 4/12 and 4/11 so far as observed by the 4/13 morning data entry crew:

1. Guidelines for updating current hospitalizations have updated to include both pending and confirmed hospitalization cases (if the state reports it). However, the number from 4/12 seems to indicate that only hospitalization numbers from confirmed cases were reported. On 4/11, the number of hospitalizations was 1252, but, the next day it dropped to 751, which is closer to the number of current hospitalizations for cases only on the dashboard. Unfortunately this is only circumstantial evidence since no screenshots for the hospitalization dashboard were recorded. 

2. The number of current ICU and ventilation were also added together for 4/11 and 4/12. However, ICU numbers already include those on ventilation, which means those numbers should be separate. Specifically, the numbers should be: 
**4/11** Curr. ICU: 426 | Curr. Vent: 283
**4/12** Curr. ICU: 440 | Curr. Vent: 294 
These numbers were inferred from the formula on the spreadsheet. 

Additionally, is there any way we can add screenshots for this page (https://www.vhha.com/communications/virginia-hospital-covid-19-data-dashboard/)? We currently take hospitalization data from it. 

Let me know if there are any issues 👍

title: SC Hospitalization numbers 3/31 - 4/2
body:
SC's hospitalization numbers look wrong from 3/31 - 4/2 https://covidtracking.com/data/state/south-carolina.

- 4/2: the number "896" appears to come from a survey of 896 cases in which 27% were reported to be hospitalized at time of reported illness. Later days use 896 * .27 = 241 as cumulative number hospitalized, so we should probably just change this day to 241.
- 3/31 - 4/1: I have no theory about the origin of these numbers. There's a survey of 424 cases in which 24% are reported hospitalized at time of illness; using the logic from 4/1 we'd have 424 * .24 = 101 as a lower bound on cumulative.

title: Confirmed vs. suspected deaths (Puerto Rico and New York City)
body:
There are reports that New York City will in the near future start reporting separate numbers for confirmed vs. suspected COVID-19 deaths, and Puerto Rico is already doing something similar as of April 9.

The data set collected in this repo might be well served to make a similar distinction as well, in order to, for example, avoid big jumps in day-to-day values that are really an artifact of that sort of reporting change.  For example, your website today reports that Puerto Rico went from 24 to 33 deaths, but in reality it went from 24 to 26 under the old standard (deaths of patients with positive test results), and a new category of suspected deaths was inaugurated with 7 cases from March (and a second batch of 7 has been added since this morning).

According to this April 8 story in Gothamist, New York city intends to start reporting counts both of confirmed and suspected COVID-19 deaths: 

- https://gothamist.com/news/death-count-expected-soar-nyc-says-it-will-begin-reporting-suspected-covid-deaths-addition-confirmed-ones 

> New York City officials will begin to count suspected COVID-19 deaths of people who die at home following a WNYC/Gothamist report revealing a staggering number of such deaths that were not included in the official tally.
>
> In a statement, Stephanie Buhle, a spokeswoman for New York City’s Health Department, said the city would no longer report only those cases that were confirmed by a laboratory test.
>
> “The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) and the NYC Health Department are working together to include into their reports deaths that may be linked to COVID but not lab confirmed that occur at home,” she said. 
>
> She didn’t say when the city would begin reporting suspected deaths along with the overall count. But the new protocol is likely to add thousands to the toll.

The story says NYC officials have given no timeline for this change, but as I mentioned above, Puerto Rico today (April 9) started reporting deaths in two similar categories as well: 

1. Deaths for which there is a positive COVID-19 test result 
2. Deaths for which there isn't such a result but the doctor indicated COVID-19 in the death certificate 

As of right now (April 9, 10pm Puerto Rico time), the project's current best source for Puerto Rico is the Institute of Statistics dashboard:

- https://estadisticas.pr/en/covid-19

...which is breaking down the deaths like this:

- 33 total ("Muertes 33")
- 7 suspected ("Registro Demográfico = 7 (21.2%)")
- 26 confirmed ("Sistema de Vigilancia = 26 (78.8%)")

title: Move 'History' management into a Database

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
# MOTIVATION

There is nothing in this problem that requires using a relational database.  The problem is just a little to simple to make it necessary.  

If we had county data, we would need it.  If we wanted to publish variants, we would need it.  But we are just managing 10 data points across 56 states and over time so it isn't really required.

However, it would be worthwhile to move the primary historical record into a DB.  It would be easier to query, be less error prone, and offer us more flexibility in the future. 

The primary advantages today are that:
  1. we could simplify the spreadsheet by eliminating its need to manage history.
  2. we could simplify the API by eliminating its need to perform derived calculation.
  3. it would make a set of ad-hoc analysis easier. 

The cost of moving to a database seem minimal and something we can do incrementally.  The only downside is another component  in the stack.

# IMPLEMENTATION

Basically, we put the DB between the spreadsheet and the API endpoints.

>    Google Spreadsheet -> Database -> API -> Web Site

When the shift leader pushes data, it would run quality checks then insert the records into a database table.  The table would replace the CHECKS tab.  The google sheet would then query the database to populate a shortened version of the CHECKS tab.  There also several other tabs that would be populated from the DB.  This process would be run through a REST API.

# REST API

The working API spec is:

     POST /publish
           Copy from the spreadsheet into the DB.
     DELETE /publish
           Rollback the published result
     GET /publish
           Get meta-data of the last publish operation

      GET /tabs/checks
            Get data to populate the CHECKS tab
      GET /tabs/checks
            Get data to populate the CHECKS tab
      GET /tabs/states
            Get data to populate the States tab
      GET /tabs/states-current
            Get data to populate the States Current tab
      GET /tabs/states-daily
            Get data to populate the States Daily tab

title: PUBLISH TIME

labels.name: Org
labels.description: Fun Organizational type stuff

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
## History

Alexis  Madrigal brought two pain points to my attention:
    1. He gets a lot of questions about why our data is out-of-sync with the state's dashboards.
    2. He feels publishing to history at 5PM (in retrospect) feels like a mistake.
    3. He likes the idea of a midnight update but worries that it would be too hard on data entry.

A group of us (Elliot/Zach/Julia/me) looked at how we could fix this.

Elliot is close to the data entry process.  He said that 5PM ET is a problem because the west coast often does not report on/at the deadline.  He thinks 8PM ET (5PM PT) is sufficient to insure that we get an update for each state every day in the history table (assuming they make one) . 

The next step in fixing this is for Alexis to find the right people to hash out the best publish date.  

## RECOMMENDATION

Our current recommendation is that we move the publish step to 8PM ET but do not change the process otherwise (keep it in the 2nd push) in the near future.  This would reduce operational pressure and make the numbers a lot more consistent.  There are other variations that I will add as comments for separate consideration.

We also recommend adding a field, called Source Date perhaps, to the published data that tells the consumers the 'as-of' date.  It would be on a per-state per-day basis.  It would clear up both the questions Alexis is getting and the questions about inconsistencies between Current and History.

My only concern about this change is if we have consumers who are news organizations with evening edition cutoffs.  I will list some alternatives in the comments.

## IMPLEMENTATION

1. [Now] Add a column called "Source Date (ET)" to the worksheet that tracks the timestamp of the data from the state and display that in the history table.  This is very close to the "Last Updated (ET)" conceptually but we may want the flexibility to put a different date into the history from the actual date that we last looked at it.

That would enable us to be clear on the website about when each record was from.  It would also enable us to leave the old date if the state fails to make an update in the day.

2. [Now] Back fill all the history records so that "Source Date (ET)" is the time of the 5PM push.  Initially, we should make it be the same time (5PM) but eventually we may update it based on the data in the CHECKS tab that records the actual time of update.

3. [Now] Tell everyone that consumes is a high profile consumer of our data to that we are planning to switch to an 8 PM ET publish time in the near future and listen for objections.

4. [Next Week] Move the history out of the spreadsheet into a relational database.  This is discussed as a separate issue but mentioned here because it is what will enable us to take the next steps without breaking the current process.  

5. [Following week]  Rebuild the history using an 8PM ET publish time using  the Checks tab, the screen shots, and backups of the worksheet.  Apply the other data fixes in the same process.   Publish it on a 'version 2' of the API.

6. [Go Live] Data Entry switches to an 8PM ET publish time.  The web site changes to use the new version of the API.  If you use the old version, the only change is that from this date forward you have data from 8PM.  If you use the new version, you get all the changes and fixes.

title: Need to resolve what to do about Guam Negatives, maybe fix historicals

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
Guam typically includes in their overall Total, their Positives, and their Negatives some people (presumably Guam residents? sailors? not sure) who have been tested at the Naval base in San Diego. It's unclear to me whether we are supposed to include these people in the Guam counts or if we are assuming that they are included in the CA counts. I thought it was the latter, but if so, we haven't been subtracting those people from the Guam numbers.  

If we are not going to count the cases tested in San Diego for Guam, then the positive number for Guam should be a calculation -- their reported Total minus the number of cases tested in San Diego. On 4/7, that would be ```121-9``` (see https://www.facebook.com/GHSOCD/photos/a.494946803880729/3822682364440473/?type=3&theater for the "121" number -- see also press release no. 60 at https://ghs.guam.gov/jic-release-no-60-eight-test-positive-covid-19-breaking-news-found-governor-leon-guerrero%E2%80%99s-facebook), which would be 112, which would be one less than was reported on 4/6. We need to figure out whether to calculate Positives for Guam or to record their total, which includes the cases in San Diego.

title: Cases where states failed to report negative tests

labels.name: stale
labels.description: An issue has had at least 15 days of inactivity

body:
I've been graphing the fraction of new test results that are positive by state.  Some states have a very low fraction of tests come back positive, except for days where no negatives were reported.
I'm reporting all the cases I saw which seem statistically unbelievable.

AL had 100% + 3/28-29
AZ had 137 of 137 + 3/28.
CA has many days of reporting 100% of 100-1000 tests positive.
DC reported no positives on 4/1.
DE reported 100% + on 3/16-3/29, under 2% + after that.
GA reported 100% + on 3/30.
HI reported 100% + 3/26-28.
KS usually has around 10% positive, but from 3/19-3/23 reported 66 positives and no negatives.
MD reported mostly 10-20% positive, but from 3/12-3/27 reported 762 positives and no negatives.
ME reported 100% positive on 3/21, 3/22, 3/27-3/30, 4/1-4/2 (225 positives), but under 2% positive all other days.
MI reported 100% positive (or more) on 3/21-3/25, 3/30-4/02 (7851 positives, 0 negatives) and some other days.
MN had 100% positive on 3/23 (over 60 positives), and under 1% positive all other days.
MO had 100% positive 3/21-3/27 (622 positives), under 2% all other days.
MS has days of suspicious 100% positive on 3/28-29.
NC had 100% positive on 3/24 (>100 positives) and under 2% all other days.
NM had 100% positive 3/21, under 20% all other days.
OH had 100% positive 3/17-3/24, 3/28, 3/29, 4/1; under 1% all other recent days.
SC has suspicious high positives 3/23, 3/26.
TN has 100% + 3/19, 3/22-23
TX had 100% + of 500 cases on 3/29, under 3% + all other days.
UT had 100% positive through 3/18, and under 1% positive all later days.
VI failed to report negatives through 3/24.
VT had 100% of 33 + on 3/23; usually 1% positive.
WA had 100% + 3/24-25, 4/01, under 1% all other recent days.
